text:
Hi everyone. I'm Jennifer 
from English with Jennifer.

Besides "Hi everyone!" how else could I address 
you all? How about, "Hi everybody," "Hi all,"

or simply, "Hey there"? We can use "everyone" 
to address a group. Good morning, everyone.

"Everybody" is considered a little more casual. 
Morning, everybody. Moving from hello, hi, hey,

we also become friendlier and more 
laid back. I grew up in Pennsylvania,

and now I live in Massachusetts, so my 
English is representative of the Northeast.

Another way I address a group of people is 
with "guys." Hi guys. Hey guys. I often do this

even if the group is made up entirely of women. 
In that case, I may also use "ladies." Hi ladies.

I can address a group of female friends this 
way or a group of female students. I might say,

"Okay, ladies. Let's get started." 
This isn't formal. I'm just addressing

the group and acknowledging that the 
group is made up of women. Of course,

some women might address their female friends 
with "girls" or "gals," but that's not my habit.

You may be wondering what the men say. Well, 
I hear them use "bro," as in, "Hey bro."

And to a group, I hear "dudes." I hear 
"guys," as in, "Hey dudes." "Hi guys."

Putting "ladies" and "gentlemen" together 
sounds formal. Good evening ladies and

gentlemen. Would I use "gentlemen" all 
by itself? That too sounds formal to me.

In a casual setting, I prefer 
"guys." Hi guys. Hey guys.

My preferences, however, won't be the 
same as other Americans in all 50 states.

Did you see my lesson on 
the US states and capitals?

I also went over the regions and 
explained that the Mason-Dixon line

is one way to divide the North and South. In the 
Northern states, I'd expect to hear, "Hi guys"

"Hey you guys." And do you know what I'd expect to 
hear more in the Southern states? "Y'all." Short

for "you all." In fact, you may hear the full 
form, too. Hi y'all. Hey y'all. How ya doin'?

Let me tell you one more way we can address a 
group of people. Do you remember my home state?

Pennsylvania. My hometown is Pittsburgh. 
Pittsburgh, PA. Well, back in the Burgh,

we have a certain way of talking, and it's called 
Pittsburghese. It's heard outside of the city,

too, so it's probably more accurate to 
call it a dialect of Western Pennsylvania.

There are words and certain pronunciation 
patterns that are unique to Pittsburghese.

We tend to address each other with "yinz." 
This word is written different ways. "Yinz."

We often say it in the phrase "yin's guys." 
Hey yinz guys. What are yinz guys doing?"

I'm not going to address the grammar of 
all these different forms of address.

It's not about what's grammatically correct. 
It's about what people say every day.

So, the next time you hear an American 
English speaker address a group,

pay attention to their word choice. You just might 
be able to figure out where the person is from.

All right, yinz guys. We're going to end here. 
I hope you found this interesting and useful.

Please like the video. As always, 
thanks for watching and happy studies!

I'd like to say a special thank you to 
a Kind-Hearted Patron who's donating two

dollars a month. Thank you, Janet. Follow me 
on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram. I invite
